## 판결문 요약


218 Va. 4. (1977)
FILLMORE B. MARTIN, JR.
v.
COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA.
Record No. 761048.
Supreme Court of Virginia.
June 10, 1977
Present:  All the Justices.
Defendant was convicted by jury of second degree murder after defense that killing was accidental.  The trial court refused instructions:  (1) that burden is upon the Commonwealth to prove that killing was not accidental; and (2) that the jury should acquit the defendant if it entertained a reasonable doubt whether killing was accidental or intentional.
1.  When evidence warrants, accused is entitled to instruction presenting his theory of accidental killing as a defense.
2.  Burden is upon the Commonwealth to prove killing is not accidental and jury should acquit defendant if it entertains reasonable doubt whether killing was accidental or intentional.
3.  Conviction of defendant of second degree murder may result from mistaken belief by jury that burden is upon defendant to prove accidental killing and failure to give instruction upon point is prejudicial error.
Error to a judgment of the Circuit Court of the City of Petersburg. Hon. Oliver A. Pollard, Jr., judge presiding.
Benjamin B. Cummings, Jr. (Cummings and Levinson, on brief), for plaintiff in error.
Alan Katz, Assistant Attorney General (Anthony F. Troy, Attorney General, on brief), for defendant in error.
Per Curiam.
